<<<api>>>: Set.addAll
<<<code>>>: set3.addAll(set1);
set3.addAll(set2);
<<<explanation>>>: You can use the addAll() method to append the elements of one set to another set. First, add all the elements of set1 to set3 using set3.addAll(set1), and then add all the elements of set2 to set3 using set3.addAll(set2). This will append the values of set2 to set1 and store them in set3.

<<<api>>>: Set.addAll
<<<code>>>: set3.addAll(set1);
set3.addAll(set2);
<<<explanation>>>: You can use the addAll() method of the Set interface to append the elements of one Set to the elements of another Set. In this case, you can simply call set3.addAll(set1) to add all elements of set1 to set3, and then call set3.addAll(set2) to add all elements of set2 to set3. This will result in set3 containing the appended elements.

<<<api>>>: Set.addAll
<<<code>>>: set3.addAll(set1);
set3.addAll(set2);
<<<explanation>>>: The `addAll` method can be used to append the elements of one set to another set. In this case, you can simply call `set3.addAll(set1)` to append the elements of `set1` to `set3`, and then call `set3.addAll(set2)` to append the elements of `set2` to `set3`. This will result in `set3` containing the concatenated elements of both `set1` and `set2`.

set3.addAll(set2);
<<<explanation>>>: The method addAll in the Set interface can be used to append the elements of one set to another set. This will result in set3 containing the combined elements of set1 and set2.

<<<api>>>: Set.addAll
<<<code>>>: set3.addAll(set1);
set3.addAll(set2);
<<<explanation>>>: You can use the addAll() method to add all elements from one set to another. In this case, you can add all elements from set1 to set3, and then add all elements from set2 to set3.

<<<explanation>>>: You can use the addAll() method of the Set interface to add all elements from set1 and set2 to set3. This will append the elements of set2 to set1 and store them in set3.
